messageBody:
pgabhart scripsit:

> If what you say regarding non-native speakers is correct (I have no
> personal experience with this), might that not be because they have
> struggled to learn a ridiculously arcane, illogical system, and then you
> throw a curve ball at them by suggesting an occasional logical change to
> what they have already attempted to commit to memory when they have
> previously seen no logic to English spelling?

I think so too. But the ability to write Inglish well is quite compatible
with a strong (even unintelligible) forren accent; non-nativ speakers
will not be able to appeal to intuition in learning to write QS-English.

> By the way, I had no difficulty reading your post in Regularized Inglish.

That's the idea. RI remooves the really arbitrary Inglish spellings while
keeping intact the existing Inglish spelling rules, complex as they ar.
For example, by writing "ar", we no longer need to memorize that "are"
does not rhyme with "bare".

If anyone is interested in RI, there's a brief explanation at
http://recycledknowledge.blogspot.com/2007/02/regularized-inglish-theory.html
and some wordlists at
http://recycledknowledge.blogspot.com/2007/02/regularized-inglish-wordlists.html .
I'll also be glad to discuss it off-list.

--
Why are well-meaning Westerners so concerned that John Cowan
the opening of a Colonel Sanders in Beijing means cowan@...
the end of Chinese culture? [...] We have had http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Chinese restaurants in America for over a century,
and it hasn't made us Chinese. On the contrary,
we obliged the Chinese to invent chop suey. --Marshall Sahlins
